column2: Rusyn: Мукачево
column3: Hungarian: Munkács
column4: Slovak: Mukačevo; see name section) is a city located in the valley of the Latorica river in Zakarpattia Oblast (province)
column5: in Western Ukraine. Serving as the administrative center of Mukachevo Raion (district)
column6: the city itself does not belong to the raion and is designated as a city of oblast significance
column7: with the status equal to that of a separate raion. The population is 86

column1: The city is now a rail terminus and highway junction
column2: and has beer
column3: wine
column8: and furniture industries. During the Cold War
column9: it was home to Mukachevo air base and a radar station.

column1: Mukachevo is a traditional stronghold of the Rusyn language
column2: and the population of Mukachevo is officially reported as 77.1% ethnic Ukrainian. There are also significant minorities of: Russians (9.0%); Hungarians (8.5%); Germans (1.9%); and Romanians (1.4%).Up until World War II and the Holocaust
column3: it was primarily a Jewish town
column4: and half the population was Jewish (see below)
column5: the rest of the population being Rusyn
column8: and other minorities. Formerly in Czechoslovakia
column10: it was incorporated into Soviet Ukraine after World War II.

column1: Etymologically the origin of the settlement's name from Hungarian. The name probably from the Hungarian surname "Muncas" - munkás (worker) which later transformed into Munkács. The other names of the city derived from this. Today
column2: there are many different ways to name Mukachevo. On 23 May 2017 the Ukrainian parliament officially renamed Mukacheve into Mukachevo
column3: a year after the city council had decided to rename the city. Previously
column4: it was usually spelled in Ukrainian as Mukacheve while Мукачів (Mukachiv) was sometimes also used.

column1: The city's name in Rusyn is Мукачево (Mukachevo)
column2: which is also the Russian transliteration -Russian: Мукачево- as well as a name adopted by the local authorities and portrayed on the city's coat of arms. Other names are Hungarian: Munkács; Romanian: Muncaci
column3: Munceag; Polish Mukaczewo; Slovak and Czech: Mukačevo; German: Munkatsch; Yiddish: מונקאַטש‎ (Munkatsh).

column1: Archaeological excavation suggest that early settlements existed here before the Middle Ages. For example
column2: a Celtic oppidum and metal works center that existed in the 3rd-1st century BC were found between the Halish and Lovachka mountains. A Thracian fort of the Iron Age (10th century BC) was found on the mountain of Tupcha. Around the 1st century the area was occupied by the Carpi people who displaced the local Celts from the area.

column1: In 895 the Hungarian tribes entered the Carpathian Basin through the Verecke Pass
column2: about 60 km (37 mi) north of present-day Mukachevo. In 1397
column3: the town and its surrounding was granted by King Sigismund of Hungary to his distant cousin
column4: the exiled prince of Grand Duchy of Lithuania Theodor Koriatovich
column5: who used to administrate the Ruthenian Podolia region of the Grand Duchy of Lithuania
column6: until was exiled for disobedience by Grand Duke Vytautas the Great in 1392. Theodor therefore became a vassal of Hungary and settled many Ruthenians in the territory. Other sources
column8: state that Theodor bought the town and the surrounding area in 1396. During the 15th century
column9: the city prospered and became a prominent craft and trade center for the region. In 1445
column10: the town became a Hungarian free royal town. It was also granted the rights of Magdeburg law.

column2: Mukachevo became part of the Principality of Transylvania. The 17th century (from 1604-1711) was a time of continuous struggle against the expansionist intentions of the Habsburg Empire for the Principality. In 1687 the anti-Habsburg Revolt of Imre Thököly started out from Mukachevo. The region also played an important role in Rákóczi's War of Independence.

column1: After the defeat of Francis II Rákóczi the city came under Austrian control in the mid-18th century as part of the Kingdom of Hungary and was made a key fortress of the Habsburg Monarchy. In 1726
column2: the Palanok Castle and the town
column3: before 1711 owned by the Rákóczi family
column4: was given by the Habsburgs to the Schönborn family
column5: who were responsible for an expansion of the town. They also settled many Germans in the territory
column6: thereby causing an economic boom of the region. During 1796–1897
column9: became a prison. The Greek national hero Alexander Ypsilanti was imprisoned at the Palanok Castle between 1821 and 1823.

column1: === Mukachevo during and after the wars ===

column2: after the American-Rusyns agreed with Tomáš Masaryk to incorporate Carpathian Ruthenia into Czechoslovakia
column3: the whole of Carpathian Ruthenia was occupied by Czechoslovak troops. On June 4
column5: Mukachevo officially became part of Czechoslovakia by the Treaty of Trianon. In November 1938
column6: a part of the territory of the former Kingdom of Hungary was re-annexed by Hungary as part of the First Vienna Award.

column1: Without delay the new authorities decreed the expulsion of all the Jews without Hungarian citizenship. As a consequence Polish and Russian Jews
column2: long-term residents of the now Hungarian-controlled Transcarpathian region
column3: and also from Mukachevo
column4: as well as the native Jews who could not prove their citizenship
column5: were deported over the Ukrainian border where their fate was sealed by the hands of a German Einsatzgruppe commando led by Friedrich Jeckeln. On August 27 and 28 1941 they were all murdered by the Germans in Kamianets-Podilskyi's massacre.

column2: Mukachevo's population still held an important Jewish component
column3: until in 1944 all the Jews were deported to Auschwitz by the Nazi German Eichmann Commando. They were the last Jewish community in Europe to succumb to the Holocaust.

column2: the Red Army stormed Carpathian Ruthenia. At first the territory was given to the reestablished Czechoslovakia
column3: then became part of the Soviet Union by a treaty between the two countries
column4: later in 1945. The Soviet Union began a policy of expulsion of the Hungarian population. In 1945
column5: the city was ceded to the Ukrainian SSR (now Ukraine). Since 2002
column6: Mukachevo has been the seat of the Roman Catholic diocese comprising Transcarpathia.

column1: Mukachevo has a humid continental climate (Köppen: Dfb).

column1: Ashkenazi & Sephardic Jews (1.1%)Residents in seven villages of the Mukachevo Raion have the option to learn the Hungarian language in a school or home school environment.

column2: an Austrian company that produces Nordic Skiing
column3: Alpine Skiing and Hockey equipment has a factory in Mukachevo. The firm benefits from provisional application on January 1
column4: 2016 of the Deep and Comprehensive Free Trade Area provisions of the Ukraine–European Union Association Agreement.

column1: See also Munkacs (Hasidic dynasty)There are documents in the Berehove State Archives which indicate that Sephardi Jews lived in Munkács and the surrounding villages as early as the second half of the seventeenth century. The Jewish community of Munkács was an amalgam of Galician and Hungarian Hasidic Jewry
column2: Orthodox Jews
column3: and Zionists. The town is most noted for its Chief Rabbi Chaim Elazar Spira who led the community until his death in 1937.

column2: Munkacs supported a large yeshiva
column3: thereby demonstrating the community's commitment to Talmudic learning and piety.

column2: yet wealthy in ideological debate
column3: the Jews of interwar Munkacs constituted almost half of the town's population. The Munkacs Jewish community was famous for its Hasidic activity as well as its innovations in Zionism and modern Jewish education.The Jewish population of Munkacs grew from 2
column5: 049 in 1891 (almost 50 percent of the total population) to 7
column8: 000 Jews still made up about half the residents
column10: the proportion had dropped to 43 percent
column12: 000 Jews. The Jews of Munkacs constituted 11 percent of the Jewry of Subcarpathian Rus.Interwar Munkacs had a very large Jewish population
column13: which was most visible on the Shabbat. On that day most stores were closed and
column15: the streets filled with Hasidic Jews in their traditional garb. The first movie house in the town was established by a Hasidic Jew
column16: and it too closed on the Shabbat and Jewish holidays.The Chief Rabbi of Munkacs
column17: Rabbi Chaim Elazar Spira (who led the community from 1913 until his death in 1937) was the most outspoken voice of religious anti-Zionism. He had succeeded his father
column19: who had earlier inherited the mantle of leadership from his father Rabbi Shlomo Spira. He was also a Hasidic rebbe with a significant number of followers. Rabbi Chaim Elazar Spira was succeeded by his son-in-law

column1: Along with the dominant Munkacser hasidic community there co-existed smaller yet vibrant Hasidic groups who were followers of the rebbes  Belz
column2: of Spinka
column3: Zidichov
column4: and Vizhnitz. By the time of the Holocaust there were nearly 30 synagogues in town
column5: many of which were Shtieblech ("[small] house" - small [Hasidic] synagogues).

column1: The Hebrew Gymnasium was founded in Munkacs five years after the first Hebrew speaking elementary school in Czechoslovakia was established there in 1920. It soon became the most prestigious Hebrew high school east of Warsaw. Zionist activism along with chasidic pietism contributed to a community percolating with excitement
column2: intrigue and at times internecine conflict
Chaim Kugel
column3: formerly director of the Munkacs gymnasium (Jewish high school) and then Jewish Party delegate to the Czechoslovak Parliament
column4: gave a speech during a parliamentary debate: "…It is completely impossible to adequately describe the poverty in the area. The Jews… are affected equally along with the rest…. I strongly wish to protest any attempt to blame the poverty of the Subcarpathian Ruthenian peasantry on the Jews"  (Kugel later got to Mandatory Palestine and eventually became mayor of the Israeli city of Holon).

column1: Government policies were covertly directed against Jews
column2: who bore a heavy share of taxes and had difficulty getting high civil service positions.In 1939
column3: the Hungarians seized and annexed Subcarpathian Rus—including Munkacs—taking advantage of the dismemberment of Czechoslovakia. Though antisemitic legislation was introduced by the Hungarian authorities
column6: remained a relative haven for Jews until Nazi Germany occupied Hungary in 1944.In the spring of 1944 there were nearly 15
column7: 000 Jewish residents of the town. This ended on May 30
column8: 1944 when the city was pronounced Judenrein (free of Jews after ghettoization and a series of deportations to Auschwitz).

column2: Mukachevo is experiencing a Jewish renaissance of sorts with the establishment of a supervised kosher kitchen
column3: a mikveh
column4: Jewish summer camp in addition to the prayer services which take place three times daily. In July 2006
column5: a new synagogue was dedicated on the site of a pre-war hasidic synagogue.

column2: 14th century. The castle of Munkács played an important role during the anti-Habsburg revolts in this territory and present-day Slovakia (1604–1711)
column3: especially at the beginning of the anti-Habsburg Revolt of Imre Thököly (1685–1688)
column4: as well as at the beginning of the revolt of Ferenc II. Rákóczi (early 18th century). This important fortress became a prison from the end of the 18th century and was used until 1897. The Greek national hero Alexander Ypsilanti was imprisoned in Munkács castle from 1821 to 1823.
